title: Cyber Daily: Biden Calls on Top Execs for Cyber Support
text:
Plus: CISOs and the board; smart-building equipment maker hacked; and more.

Cybercriminals' Ten Favorite Industries

The list may surprise you.... New avenues of attack, brought forth by the COVID-19 pandemic, threaten life online as we now know it.

Cyber Summit

President Biden on Wednesday met in the East Room of the White House with executives from tech giants like Amazon and Google, as well as banks including JPMorgan Chase.

Outreach: President Biden urged executives from technology, banking and energy firms at a White House summit on Wednesday to shore up their cybersecurity and bolster training programs, the administration's most direct exhortation to the private sector to help end a stream of hacks that have disrupted U.S. businesses and infrastructure.

Mr. Biden called cybersecurity "the core national-security challenge we're facing." Administration officials have hinted that mandatory requirements could be in the works if voluntary guidelines aren't widely adopted.

"Ultimately, we've got a lot of work to do," Mr. Biden said.

The meeting with executives from Amazon, JPMorgan Chase and other firms yielded multi-million dollar commitments to invest in cyber defenses and educational initiatives as the Biden administration rolls out an array of projects to protect federal computer networks.

More Cyber News

Smart-building equipment maker hacked. Beverly, Mass.-based Delta Electronics Manufacturing Corp. disclosed an unspecified malware incident that resulted in unauthorized access to the personal data of about 196 individuals. Delta Electronics revealed the episode in a letter to Maine regulators, saying it became aware of the episode on July 23 and notified the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Scammers and hackers see new frontier in NFT art. NFTs, or nonfungible tokens, are supercharging the art market, but users warn they have a dark side. Scammers and hackers are increasingly exploiting security gaps in the rapidly expanding marketplace—and artists and collectors who aren't crypto-literate are proving easy marks. Common frauds include creating phony NFT works and fake platforms that purportedly sell art, but actually steal credit-card details. Phishing schemes and viruses can drain users' digital wallets, or online accounts can store people's financial data and cryptocurrency wealth. (WSJ)

27%

Percentage of facilities managers who say their operations technology has been breached in the past year, according to a survey of such managers in the U.S., China and Germany from industrial manufacturer Honeywell. (Security Week)

Newsletter Extra: Dealing with the Board

If any good can come from the serious cyberattacks at networking software maker SolarWinds Corp., energy transporter Colonial Pipeline Co., telecom firm T-Mobile US Inc. and numerous hospitals, it's this: corporate boards get it now.

So says Myrna Soto, chief executive of Apogee Executive Advisors LLC and former chief information security officer at Comcast Corp. and MGM Resorts International.

"Events over the last year, in my opinion, have assisted in elevating the dialogue in the boardroom," said Ms. Soto, speaking on Wednesday at a WSJ Pro virtual event. She serves as a director at Banco Popular de Puerto Rico and Spirit Airlines Inc., among others.

Chief information security officers should expect to field questions from the board after high-profile hacks, Ms. Soto said. "Whenever there's an incident in another organization that's headline-worthy, immediately prepare to explain to your board why [your company] may be different or how you also may be at risk."

Cybersecurity issues are rising on the agenda of a typical board meeting, but many CISOs still struggle to get the right level of attention from this vital constituency, said Scott Howitt, chief information officer at cyber vendor McAfee Corp., also speaking at the event.

At board meetings, CISOs sometimes lapse into techno-speak, neglecting to explain cyber risk in business terms, said Mr. Howitt, who has also served as security chief at MGM Resorts, as well as at retailer JCPenney.

Being a CISO, he said, is 70% listening to understand the challenges in a given business unit.

"How many people are hitting the firewall and things like that—not so interesting," he said. "But if a significant revenue stream is taken offline, how would we react?"

—Kim S. Nash

On hold: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Global Inc. has delayed plans to expand to Britain and Europe, partly due to political and regulatory challenges, according to people familiar with the matter, the latest illustration of the uphill battle Chinese tech firms face in Western markets. Chinese officials are conducting a cybersecurity investigation of the Beijing-based company. (WSJ)
